text.p: The following are the main stories from Wednesday's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The newspaper editorial is a New York Times article that says Albanian and Serbian elections this year were not fair.
- Albania's veto earlier this month of Yugoslavia's membership in the Central European Initiative has increased problems faced by Albanian traders in Montenegro.
- Pyramid schemes have reduced by 40-50 percent the sale of consumer products in Albania.
- An Albanian carrying seven kilograms of heroin, destined for Italy, was stopped by police on the Greek-Macedonian border, according to Greek television stations.
- Heavy rain on Tuesday flooded some 200 hectares of land and destroyed about 20 houses and a part of the railway in the northern district of Lezhe.
- An Albanian court sentenced a former soldier to 15 years inprisonment in absentia for killing a person who was trying to flee the country six years ago.
- The new Tirana mayor Albert Brojka re-organised the structure of the city hall in an attempt to make it more efficient.
- Italian police have arrested a band of Albanian involved in smuggling immigrants, prostitution and drug traffic.
- The U.S. dollar has strengthened to above 100 leks after dipping to 96 leks earlier this month as Albanians sought leks to put into pyramid schemes.
- Albanian director Kujtim Cashku said his film "Colonel Bunker" stands a good chance of winning an Oscar at the next Academy Awards.
- Albania's Defence Ministry denied media reports that it breached a United Nations arms embargo by smuggling military equipment to Rwanda.
- Mercedes-Benz, Volskswagen and Fiat will present their new cars in a fair in Tirana at the end of the month.
